If you want a medieval FTL then this game is fit for the job, but it doesn't excel at it. I'm going to break this down as simple as I can because there is a lot to chew.

[Lazy Version] The sound is pleasing. It looks like an old disney cartoon. Characters are distinct but distinct enough to warrant more depth. The enemies are cool but lacking variety. On sale it's a yes, full price it's a maybe.

The sound is fantastic in this game. Not just the music but the way it softens when you're in a menu or how it changes tempo at the end of a battle. Something about it is just very pleasing to the ears. The music in each stage is also great without being so memorable that it gets repetitive.

The visuals are very reminiscent of the days of VHS tape cartoons. Think disney's robin hood or the fox and the hound. So if you're into that sort of thing, there you go. Another thing to note is the way the map folds out in little hexagons as you travel. Whenever you go to click on something the hexagon pops up and back down with a little wooden thump. Like you're playing a game with miniatures.

The characters are a little bland, which is disappointing. In FTL (my only real comparison to this game) you grew a little more attached to the hirelings. They were bland by design so you put a little something into them, but the mercenaries you use in this game are give distinct features and names. It just isn't early enough to warrant individuality. You only get a handful of them so the very least the designers could have done was give them a little flesh. Which isn't a huge problem until you think of longevity.

The Combat is fun, but not as diverse as it could be. Each zone has different mobs, with their own abilities and such. By the time you figure one out and get the hang of it, you get to another zone and get rocked all over again. Which I love, it keeps you on your toes as you advance, but there is no mixing. Which seems odd for any unit based strategy game. It's not repetitive, at least as far as I've played, but it would make things a lot more interesting if it did. Other than that the combat is a chess match of positions and unit abilities and chaining attacks. If you love strategy you'll like the combat.

I think that's enough information for anyone on the fence, so I'll stop there.

reviewText:
I wanted and tried to like the game, but it's too firmly up in the 'true hardcore only, no girls need to apply' treehouse, and not in a good way.

I'm a big fan of roguelikes (both Dungeon Crawl, ToME and FTL, Spelunky variety) and have spent hundreds of hours on HoMM/King's Bounty series, so Crowntakers looked right up my tree. I like the art style and the stripped-down resource/inventory management/crafting systems work surprisingly well. Actually, it has all the groundwork needed for an excellent game. And then it kicks you in the balls and runs away.

What do I mean? Well, for one, bosses tend to have gimmicks and gotchas. It means that you're unlikely to win a boss fight on the first go, because while you figure out what to do with him, you're probably lying down on the ground already anyway. So it's more Nethack than DC:SS.

The choices you make in exploration seem to be mostly based on luck, like FTL. There's no way to know beforehand if you should observe the snails or dig the ground in a cave, so there's no risk/reward mechanism, just guessing and being punished or rewarded. At least now you have a vague idea of the threat level of random mobs on the map (but not story encounters or strength increases... until you've died and learned from this, because there might not be any way to recover from a mistake).

In battles everything is dependent on keeping the main character alive (you can revive mercenaries, but once the main guy goes down it's Game Over), which makes you play the battles in a very conservative manner. Even if you have concentrated on building up nothing but health and dodge skills for the main guy, he can easily die in one or two turns (at least early on) if you've made the slightest error in the positioning. It is 'classic roguelike', but goes against everything that the genre has learned and moved towards to in the last decade. Especially in games with permadeath mechanic there has to be some way to ensure an error margin for the player, and one-shot death doesn't allow for it.

I'm particularly frustrated, because there's lots to love in the game, but playing it makes me feel as if I'm in an abusive relationship. There is an easy mode, but it relies on grinding more than anything.

The skill in the Crowntakers comes not so much in mastering its mechanics and making informed choices, but learning its patterns and 'gaming' the mechanics. I'm sure there are people who are into it, but I'll be looking forward to the developers' next game. They do show a lot of promise.

reviewText:
So I have about 15 hours logged in this game. I've unlocked all of the characters, and all of their seperate loadouts. I did all of this on easy, which is the only game mode available to you until you beat the game once.

This game is actually a lot of fun. I really enjoy a lot of aspects of it.  It does a good job of blending the resource managment that you find necessary in roguelikes with the meaningful strategic choices that are present in any good tactical RPG. The engine works pretty well, I've only had one freeze, and one sound bug. But it autosaves before every fight, so no crash is every too big of a deal.

My biggest problem with this game is that it feels, mechanically and systemically, unbalanced. It seems to work at first glance, but the more you play it the more you find yourself consistently frustrated by stupid things.

A perfect example of this is their equiptment upgrade paths. In the game, you upgrade your character's equptment by using upgrade materials (Iron->Steel->Gold for Weapons;Cloth->Leather->Gold for Armor). The upgrade itself doesn't add any stats to the equiptment, but rather adds a slot to it. That slot can be filled with a rune to grant various bonuses. The important thing to note here is that any upgrade is, by itself, useless. Without a rune, there is no reason to upgrade, These materials can be found in the world, or bought from the blacksmith. Now here's the thing: Each character you recruit into your party needs to start with iron before moving onto steel, but iron stop showing up in shops or the world around zone 3 of 8.  So unless you horde enough iron to upgrade all of your future recruits by the time you leave the third zone, you can never upgrade them. And this directly goes against what a good roguelike player would do. They wouldn't waste money (which is used to do pretty much everything in the game) on materials that they can't use for another 50% of the campaign. Its locking away valuble gold in useless assets.

This is an EASY problem to fix. Just have certain events have an option to drop iron/cloth in later zones. Boom. Done. But this level of imbalance persists throughout the game across a lot of little mechanics.


My other big concern is that the difference between 'easy' and 'norma' is the difference between night and day. The difficult jump is so large in fact, that it qualifies as a design flaw in my opinion. Not necessarily how hard it is, but the fact that you force the player to play easy mode, a lot, before unlocking normal, and then expose them, with no transition, to the insanely more difficult normal mode just seems silly. Not only that, but the differences between the two modes isn't actually explained. They mention that your characters will all start from level 1, and you are foced to fight the bosses at the end of each level, but that's just a small part of what makes it so different.

The differences I've noticed are:
Characters start from level 1
Fewer rewards from battles
Significantly faster enemy growth
Must fight bosses
Majority of objects in the world are now locked, and require a lockpick
Lockpicks no longer sold in stores
Res scrolls no longer sold in stores
Mercenary selected is restricted to 2 ranom mercs selected from the roster of 9 at each tavern (biggest and most significant change after the level honestly)

I am going to keep playing normal, but as of right now (especially considering how luck dependant the combat can feel sometimes) I fail to see how it's beatable.


TL;DR REVIEW:

Good game. Needs a few patches. Don't get excited about Normal mode though, just play and enjoy the mandatory Easy mode when its still beatable and fun.

reviewText:
Yes, the size and scope of this roguelike fantasy tactical FPG does feel a bit mobilely; however, it's full game with no pay-to-win hooks. The closet relative of which I'm aware is FTL in the sense that it's a game of multiple stages where the objective is to gather enough resources to beat the final boss, and most of the time (even on the Easy setting) you will not be able to do so because of the RNG.

I defeated Easy in about 20 hours, and took about 8 attempts to do so once the other stage bosses were clear and I am thoroughly lame. (For instance, I did not even realize in over 8 hours of play that you could at any time in battle select of any your characters to use the next action point in a turn, and, thus, was limiting myself to the random order that the characters were selected by the game.) Each of the 9 available characters has two unlockable forms (each with one unique skill) in additional to its starting form, and so it's worth paying attention to what it takes to unlock the additional forms as you work through Easy, because otherwise you will probably have to grind a bit on Easy to do so. The additional forms are not necessary but do add variety to the available tactics.

Normal is much more challenging, and I cannot imagine with my poor play skills the kind of luck that it would take for me to beat it. The bosses reset in every run on Normal, and every character starts from level 1, and so experience and food become much more relevant resources.

Like Nethack, it's a fun challenge even if you have no resonable expectation of ever defeating it. It's quite a bit simpler and shorter than Nethack. (No item testing required in this game: once you know what an item does, it will do the same thing in all games and so you can safely sell the 4 poison kinds of muchrooms, for instance, once you know which they are.) You can easiliy get through even a comparatively succesful run attempt in less than 2 hours. I thoroughly enjoy this game.

I really wanted to like this game, but the reality is that while there are some good concepts here, it's really quite an annoying piece of a rogue-like RPG.

The good:

1. Once you unlock them, your hero and any mercenaries you hire have up to 3 different possible configurations to start with
2. The graphics are charming
3. The equipment upgrade system is interesting to a certain point
4. The combat system is quite good to a certain point...

The bad:

1. The game is an incremental upgrade system that basically means it's impossible to finish it on at least the first several attempts.  I finally managed to beat it on easy after about 5 or 6 run throughs - but only because you and your mercs can keep your experience points between restarts.  I can't even contemplate how it would be possible to defeat this game on Normal, where you and the mercs all start at level 1!
2. The combat can be brutally difficult, with some of the encounters you face nigh on impossible - with mobs often doing absolutely impossible stuff that your characters cannot do.
3. The sheer randomness of most encounters where you just don't know if a choice is going to give you something positive, negative or otherwise.
4. Random combat starting positions, often meaning that you're caught spread out with enemies all around you and no way to get into a defensive postion.

Crowntakers is a pretty damn good game. It’s quite difficult, even for a rogue-like, and will definitely challenge you. Even playing through on easy can be fairly tough depending on your luck.

The art style is really nice, and definitely suits the game itself, which is always a good thing. The gameplay is certainly interesting - it’s a fair bit of fun and does take some learning. There is no tutorial so you have to learn the game for yourself, which personally, in a game like this, I think was a good thing, particularly since it’s not overly complicated and I did enjoy working things out.

The combat system is well thought out and quite easy to understand, but does have some little intricacies to it, such as the opportunity mechanic. Also, it’s clear what you’re doing before you do it, so you can’t really blame the game if you screw up, particularly when it comes to combat, which is certainly important in any rogue-like. (for example, the game displays whether you are at risk of taking damage from opportunity strikes, while also clearly displaying things like directions units can hit, where you need to be to backstab etc. It also shows if a ranged unit will be able to attack a certain unit from a new position before you move it – something not enough games get right).

The levelling up and equipment systems complement each other nicely and would allow for a variety of possible builds for a character. The rune system is a really cool idea – when you upgrade equipment instead of getting just a flat bonus you get spots for runes which give things like crit or dodge chance, lower cooldowns or armor. It combos nicely with the stats you can pick when you level up, giving you a degree of freedom when it comes to

So, while normal mode will certainly be the favourite of all of the hardcore rogue-like fans, I think the easy difficulty is a welcome addition, since this game is very hard, and letting you keep that little bit of progress really does give you that motivation to keep trying, because you get a little bit closer to winning every time. It also means newer players who may not be particularly experience with rogue-likes aren’t just thrown into the deep end and scared off by the difficulty.

An underrated little turn-based strategy rogue-lite, don't be fooled by my low in-game time, I've sunk serious hours into this game on iPad and enjoyed it so much I got it for Steam too.

Pros:

- Loads of replayability, like FTL it takes many, many playthroughs to come across all the game's many events and unlock everything.

- Great soundtrack, medieval but catchy!
- Solid art style.

Cons:

- Story's a bit meh, it does the job of framing what you're doing and paints a nice picture, but don't expect to care about the characters or world much.
- The audio suffers from bugs, occassionally the music will cut out, leaving eerie ambient noise, other times it plays two pieces at once, very annoying and the fantastic soundtrack deserves better.
- Once you realise the timer doesn't really effect the gameplay, and the ending even less, it becomes irrelevant and can be ignored, which is a shame as it could've added another dimension to the gameplay.
- Depending where you are on the learning curve and what the game throws at you, can be too hard or too easy, thankfully the game's enjoyable enough to keep playing either way.

Lastly, not to write off anyone's review, but it's worth bearing in mind that the game received a hefty rebalance a few months ago and in my view made it work a lot better, so post-June 9th reviews may reflect the current game experience better.

Crowntakers is a a casual, colorful tactical turn based game.  I thought I would give it a try...and was really surprised by how many great game design choices the developers made!

Examples of great game design:
+ Every map is randomized - not only the map layout, but also your units' positions!
+ The fight is not going well and you're in a bind.  Do you use potions now or save them for a later fight?
+ Mercenaries have different abilities, and choosing which mercs to use (and their variant skills) and building combos make it fun and replayable
+ Normal is quite difficult, so the ability to carry over experience after defeat in Easy mode is a great option.  (I was able to beat the game in my 2nd easy playthrough, but it was close!)
+ Runes for your fighters have good variety - enough to make choosing which merc gets which runes important for battles.
+ A new merc can be unlocked with each playthrough, which incentivizes playing it again and again, even if you've won already (winning one time through might only take 3-4 hours)
+ Your hero and each merc have unlockable skills. To unlock them you have to do perform various feats with each hero, which incentivizes you to change your tactics each playthrough.
+ On the main map, at each cave/house/roundtower/etc, you can only choose to perform one action out of 2-5 options. Once you've done the action, you have to live with your choice!  On the next playthrough, you can choose differently...

reviewText:
I was really pleasantly surprised by this game.  It's got a lot of charm, everything is really well polished, and it's decently challenging without being too punishing.  I'm a big fan of rogue-lites and tactical strategy games and this does both portions justice, although with only a moderate amount of depth.  Think of it as a really well-done, casual-minded rogue-lite.  8/10

Starting off can be a bit rough, but once you unlock some of the 'good' characters, like the scout, the game becomes much, much easier.  Also 'easy' mode is the way to go while you're getting a hang of the game and still unlocking.  A lot of the problems I had in the beginning were from rushing and not exploring, thinking the time pressure element was more important than it actually is.  Unfortunately, once you get the hang of it, it's a bit too easy.  And if you get the DLC, the game is also substantially easier, but does have more 'fun' content.

Combat is the major portion of the game and I'm glad to say it does it quite well.  Certain mercs synergize quite nicely.  The map is never 'too big' and almost always fits entirely on the screen.  You always start first, but don't get to choose positioning, which is a fair enough tradeoff.  Most battles will be over in a few rounds.  Only the bigger boss battles stretch out and try your resources and resourcefulness.  Stun is a bit overpowered, which makes the barbarian maps a bit of a pain, but there are multiple options for avoiding fights, so it's by no means a gamebreaker.

There's a good number of 'fun things' like unlocks and achievements to keep you playing after you've won once.  A single run can last a few hours if you explore all the nooks and crannies.  I'm hoping they release some more DLC with an extended challenge.  Overall, it's a really fun game that I'd totally recommend for a weekend romp.  That said, $15 is a bit much, but during seasonal sales, it goes for much, much less making it an insta-buy.

reviewText:
Its pretty fun in short bursts. Just a simple turn based Roguelike with some persistent stats in the starting game mode. The graphics are neat, the art style reminds me of an older Disney cartoon movie, like the Sword in the Stone. The music is appropriate kind of cheerful fantasy style.

The controls are entirely mouse driven, and easy to use.

It has an option for a controller, but I cant get it to work, and I have no idea why you'd use a controller for this game. Trust me, I have a physical disability, and have to use a controller for most M&K based games that rely on realtime keyboard for movement and mouse for options/looking around. I'd be the first to be asking for controller support if the game needed it. This one doesn't, but has it.

The full review:
The help files suck and I still dont know what all those symbols with the hand and arrow on the right hand side does (Hold in inventory, give to someone, drop?)Theres not to much in the way of deep tactics, but its entertaining.

Basically, you move around a hex board. You choose the direction you go, and then you walk to the next crossroads. Sometimes theres a place you can interact with (search a cottage, visit a merchant or blacksmith, an inn, cave , a fight ect). Random events happen at these places. Usually searching for small items, but other things such as HP or gold gain/loss, or nothing at all

The blacksmith and inn are used to improve your weapon/armor, buy things, rest and buy food, hire mercenaries. To improve your weapons you need to buy or loot a certain item shown in your inventory screen then take that item to the blacksmith and pay a fee. The item is upgraded. Then you take armor/weapon runes and put them in the slots you get from upgrading. The runes have different effects, and are swappable but only armor runes work with armor and vice versa.

Mercenaries are the people you hire at the inn to help you fight. They can gain XP and some of their their XP is persistant even after you die. So they get better and better as you go. Every mercenary is slightly different. I have found an archer and a fighter. Each character has 2 special skills they can use to help them in battle, and they are all different for each mercenary that Ive found so far.

There is a day/night cycle and after every 24 hours (shown in the lower left corner) the enemies get stronger a bit. So you have to balance searching everything and getting to the end of the map. The maps are random for each playthrough, so you dont know where everythings going to be.

Fighting is done on a turn based hex grid. Its simple. Move, attack, and choose facing. The arrow that is yellow instead of red is the chars back. Backstabbing does extra damage so facing matters. There is permadeath, so when the hero dies, you have to start again. Your mercenaries keep their XP (depending on gameplay mode), though, so its not like everythings completely lost.

Seems like itd be really fun on a phone if I was stuck waiting for something. I dont do the phone-as-gaming-device thing though.

reviewText:
[Spoiler-Free Review]

Crowntakers aims to usurp your playtime with accessible, character-based, combat on a grid. While certain elements leave something to be desired, ultimately, it's a game better than the sum of its parts.

Characters and game mechanics make the game.
You start out with a single hero, and gradually recruit mercenaries you meet in your travels (up to four extras per run). The mercenaries come with skills unique to them, and part of the fun is figuring out their strengths/weaknesses. In addition, each character comes with additional unlockable archetypes (i.e. skillsets), something I really appreciated. It made for fun rewards, a reason to use characters you wouldn’t naturally be inclined to, and gave everyone the potential to become useful where their default skills might be lacking.

The storyline is extremely light and just barely passable...
I get that the game is more about proper resource management, the challenges you overcome, and the people you meet along your adventure, but a narrative consisting of two basic strings of storyline text (intro and finale), doesn't leave a whole lot of room for extrapolation. The story doesn't incentivize the player or encourage you to replay the adventure, it doesn't even help develop character.  It’s, summarily, placeholder text for a better story not yet conceived. Thankfully it’s also skippable (for the most part). Even the bits that come up when you investigate a new location are easily ignored, as the choices are basically, 'You wanna fight, or not?' (the answer is yes btw, always yes, and you don’t need to read through a snippet about an old woman begging for food to know it).

Short in length, but highly replayable
A typical run takes about an hour or so to complete (once you understand how everything works), and you will be required to run through the game more than once to unlock achievements and mercenaries. Where the story was lacking, the achievements are not, and provide ample reason to go back and play through the game over and over again.

Rogue-light, an easy mode that actually works.
Start with Easy Mode if you want to give yourself the best chance at enjoying this game. It’s a welcome entry point to the game mechanics and world. You play through the story the same way you would in Normal Mode, but with the added advantage that you don't lose experience and levels gained in each run. Failure never feels quite so devastating when you know your characters are going to retain their stats (for the most part) in subsequent attempts. By the time you’ve completed your Easy run, you’ll be more than ready for Normal. In either mode, the only thing poking and prodding you to go forward is that enemies grow stronger by the in-game day.

Exploration and Battles remain fun.
Collecting items and equipment, and taking on enemy mobs are rewarding experiences. The danger in a game so focused though, is that the game can become monotonous if the formula isn’t changed all that much from start to finish. Having special elements based around each area helps remedy this to a point, instead of fighting soldiers and thieves at every turn, some areas house natural threats/inhabitants and mysterious landmarks.

The storybook art style works marvellously for a game like this.
Exploring the map is enjoyable. Areas (in and out of battle) are vibrant and interesting. Each area has a unique look to it, and the contrast between them helps keep the game feeling fresh.

The soundtrack is an argument for quality vs quantity.
In a game you're likely to spend a considerable amount of time playing and replaying, 2-3 songs isn't really going to suffice. The tracks are good, and melt into the backdrop as you play, but even the best song is going to feel repetitive if it's the sole musical leg on which a game stands. The sound effects are satisfying though, my favourite being the sucking sound your cursor makes when hovering over items in your inventory.

The world is always changing… I think.
I can't tell whether the maps are randomized. I've played through the game 4 or 5 times across each of the difficulties and each time, the maps kind of mesh together in my mind. It's not that it's overly samey, it’s just not immediately clear to me how the maps are differentiated. It could just be a by-product of the fog-of-war and the small scope of each area. However, it might be saying something that the random world doesn’t feel very random.

Final Thoughts.
If I was to sum this game up in a word, it'd be barebones. Crowntakers is entertaining however, and I don't feel bad in recommending it to anyone. I just hope the devs continue to expand the offering. This game really deserves it.

It's a small but decent rogue-like.

Tl;dr
It's a fine small indie game (5-7h core gameplay length), but I'd only recommend getting it if it's 30% off or less.


You start with one hero, and as you progress through the rather small maps, you will get the option to hire one extra hero at the start of each new map.
You gain XP, advance the heroes' stats, equip them with gear and mod the gear with crystals.

I failed a handful of times, before I managed to beat the game (too slowly for the achievement); This took me roughly 5 hours.
I then did it again a couple of times before I managed to beat it well within the time for the achievement.

The game gets progressively easier each time you restart, which both works and feels fine, but it's still annoying to think that your first time is the hardest possible scenario.
On my first couple of attempts, I could only hire 3/5 heroes.
When I beat the game the first time, I had 4 heroes.
After the next retry, I was given the option to fill all 5 available hero slots... and the mods I found were also getting progressively more powerful with each new game I started...

I think what annoys me the most, is that the game is build like a rogue-like, but it gets easier each time you play it. It's as if they made the game as a single-playthrough experience which lowers the difficulty automatically each time you fail (which would be a fine small game IMO), but then they added the replayability unlocks to it...



There are unlockable heroes, which are limited to unlock only one new hero per playthrough, as well as hero-variations if you have used each hero well enough (i.e. kill 30 enemies with Hero A1 to get A2. Get Hero A to 10 strength to unlock Hero A3)

This game.
This game seemly takes RNG to it's absolute limits in what can happen to your party. One second you could be doing perfectly, all your party members are full health, and full power. Everything looks nice and fluid and the soundtrack, while not amazing, does a good job of fitting the game.

The most Meh thing about Crowntakers is that they want to charge you money to get the game.

Once the player has exited a map he cannot return to it.  As a result, if the player encounters a situation which he cannot beat in his current condition there is rarely a way to improve the character and try again.

Combat begins with players characters  deployed on a hed grid map, frequently with no opponents in view nor any suggestion of their location.  Nearly always surprised even though the text says that player is aware of opponents.  It is not uncommon for player's characters with seven or eight hit points each to face four or more opponents each with six to fifteen hit points, when played on easy.

That the devs assume that placing the player into situations in which he has no chance of success makes for amusing game play is but one mark of their shortsightedness.

Camping & inns do not replenish hit points and rewards for the rare battle victory are inadequate for character survival.

There is no sense of progress.  No feeling of having learned how to increase the character's chance of success in subsequent games.

The entire game could be condensed to having the player roll a die at the beginning and then declaring him failed or victorious.

All in all a poorly designed game utterly lacking in the elements that that would make it enjoyable.

The game is not difficult it is highly random with an extremely restrictive choice basis.  That means that the player's chance of completing each level is very small.

The first level has eight to ten encounters.  Each encounter has two or three options.  Each option may have up to a half dozen outcomes.  Since each encounter occurs once per game sampling each of the possible  options on the first level  alone requires between 64 and 512 plays.

It is relativly easy to reach the second map but highly unlikely that the play weill have gained enough knoweldge/experience from the first map to effect his chances of surviving to the third.

The second map is a bit less random.  It has more combat encouters  but opponents are significantlhy stronger.  I place the probability of surviving any one combat between one-quarter and one-third call it 7/24.  There are four combat encounters, I believe.  The chance of surviving all of them would be about 1/140.  It takes 97 plays to have a 50% chance to complete this level.

If you are willing to play the game a couple hundred times you might make it to the next map.

Though there a many player choices on each map the outcome of each choice has a high variability.  That means that very little of the information you have garnered from previous game play will contribute to your choices in your current game.

Since each map has few opportunities for character improvement unpassable roadblocks are common.

It is these last two points where this game fails as a rogue-like.  The best rogue-like games present problems for the player and provide him with opportunities to surmount them.  The worst rogue-like games simple provide scads of random events.

WazHack & Bionic Dues ae both good rogue-like games.  Crowntakers is not.
